data.title: More tree focus changes
data.body: @joaomoreno fyi

data.title: Output in horizontal panel
Keyboard accessibility and focus indication
data.body:
- [x] win @alexandrudima 
- [x] mac @joaomoreno 
- [x] linux @isidorn 

We no longer hide the focus outline when using the `Tab` key to move focus into an element in the DOM. We added more support for using `Tab` and `Arrow` keys to navigate between UI controls in the workbench and editor.

**Note**: Enable accessibility mode in the editor to be able to tab out of it (`F1 | "Toggle Use of Tab Key..."`)

**Note**: You might end up in a situation where you do not see any focus indication. Open the console and type `document.activeElement` to find out where you are currently at and file a bug if you think something is wrong.
- verify you can use `Tab` to jump to UI controls and you get meaningful focus indication
- verify you can use the `Arrow` keys in UI control groups to jump between controls (e.g. in action bars)
- verify you never end up in a situation where you can not continue to tab out of a control

data.title: HTML Preview: use custom CSS for scrollbars
data.body:
The markdown preview uses its own CSS for styling scrollbars so that they look similar to the scrollbars in VS Code and not like the ugly native ones. The CSS is defined for every theme we have starting here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/languages/markdown/common/markdownWorker.ts#L38

There is also some CSS defined in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/languages/markdown/common/markdown.css that we maybe should take into the HTML preview:
- size images to a maximum of 100% so that they do not cause horizontal scrolling
- styling for anchors
- styling for focused elements (when you tab around)

The rest of the rules are just for making markdown look better and probably does not apply for the raw HTML preview.

@jrieken fyi

data.title: Creating a comment doc block
data.body:
Is there anything that will allow for shorthand creation of documentation?

So for example, in C# if I type:

`///` and press <kbd>Enter</kbd>

It would create a doc comment block

```
/// <summary>
///     Summary of my item
/// </summary>
```

It would add things such as:
- Summary
- Parameters
- Return
- Etc.

data.title: Changed a setting I can't figure out, can't debug, stuck. New student trying to use for JavaScript.
data.body:
I have used Visual Studio 2013 and 2015 for Python coding and debugging. I was just learning it I just started a second semester in programming. Then I read about Visual Studio Code which seemed pretty cool as it says to be a somewhat lightweight and easy IDE and yes it absolutely sure is! I just cannot get the debugging mode to work for the life of me, can't figure out how to run the program, just 3 basic outputs. I changed a location setting somewhere in a wizard to the folder on my computer that I thought I was supposed to do and now I get this error:

request 'launch': program 'c:\Users\Daniel\OneDrive\Documents\School\COP2800 - JAVA\Assignment 1\app.js' does not exist

Now I can't figure out where this app.js file even is by doing file explorer searches, and I have uninstalled, restarted, then reinstalled back into the computer and all my previous settings remained. I had no option to remove and do a clean install or something. So I don't know what to do because I'd like to use code as opposed to eclipse or notepad or jgrasp but I have messed it up somehow. I'm reading everything I can from the Microsoft docs so we will see. I am new to all this, sorry for the newbie stuff.

Adding a global Env to the extension API

This will add a global Env variable that can contain information about VSCode. 

The Evn variable for now contains: 
- Version
- Machine Id. 
- Session Id. 
- Locale (to be implemented).

data.title: breakpoints don't work on symlinked files on windows

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Using "npm link" to create a symlink from one node project's node_modules to another a project on windows server 2012 R2.  This sets up a directory in node_modules that is a symlink to the "required" project.  VS Code breakpoints in the linked projects' files don't work. I can step into/step through these files - that all seems to work fine, but breakpoints are ignored.  Breakpoints do work in the referencing project. 

Here's repro steps:
1.  Unpack this zip file:
   [symlinkBreakpoint.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/98401/symlinkBreakpoint.zip)
2.  cd B 
3.  run "npm link" command
4.  cd A
5.  run "npm link B" command
6.  open VS code in A directory. 
7.  Set a breakpoint on line 1 of a.js
8.  launch VS Code debugger.  Initial breakpoint will get hit. 
9.  on line 2 of a.js, step into b.foo() call.   (step into works)
10.   set a breakpoint on line 5 of  b.js
11.  hit f5 (continue).

Expected:  breakpoint on line 5 of b.js will be hit. 

Actual:  breakpoint is skipped & program exits.

data.title: Omnisharp ignores runtime and architecture in global.json
data.body:
I have a variation of https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/126. I'm running VSCode 0.10.6 on Win 7 x64. My `global.json`:

```
{
  "sources": ["src", "test"],  
  "sdk": {
        "version": "1.0.0-rc1-update1",
        "runtime": "coreclr",
        "architecture": "x64"
  }
}
```

and `dnvm list` shows

```
Active Version           Runtime Architecture OperatingSystem Alias
------ -------           ------- ------------ --------------- -----
       1.0.0-rc1-update1 clr     x64          win             clr
  *    1.0.0-rc1-update1 coreclr x64          win             coreclr, default
```

When I start VS Code I see this in the Omnisharp log:

```
[INFORMATION:OmniSharp.Dnx.DnxPaths] Looking for sdk version in 'c:\Users\blabla\Development\oslo-group\global.json'.
[ERROR:OmniSharp.Dnx.DnxPaths] The specified runtime path '1.0.0-rc1-update1' does not exist. Searched locations C:\Users\blabla\.dnx\runtimes\dnx-clr-win-x86.1.0.0-rc1-update1
C:\Users\blabla\.dnx\runtimes\kre-clr-win-x86.1.0.0-rc1-update1
```

Apparently it searches for runtime `clr` and `x86`, which of course is not installed on my system.

Any ideas how to fix this?

data.title: Weird black squares all over the place
data.body: Hello guys, first of all nice job with VSCODE, love it! Not 100% sure if someone else report it, so rather again. Im working with vscode about few weeks and almost every week I'm experiencing really weird rendering issue. It's starting with small black squares which are randomly jumping all over the screen (as you type) and then turn out into something like that: No extensions installed, pure vscode, OSX (retina, el captain) Version 0.10.6 (0.10.6) Build a80232bbcfe8a5cdad1ebc98638673d9dcb02458 Probably related to this issue, chrome is doing the same along with vscode (but only if you actually run vscode).

data.title: Zoom level reset when (auto)saving tasks.json
data.body:
You lose the current zoom level when editing and saving tasks.json. I expect the current zoom level to be kept as it was before saving.

Repro steps:
1. open tasks.json
2. change the zoom level
3. make any random edit
4. manually save the file or autosave kicks in
OUTCOME: zoom level is reset

VS Code version: 0.10.6

data.title: Type checker continues type checking after type conversion removed
data.body: Repro step: 1) Add .d.ts file that contains a type definition for a class that doesn't contain a member referenced in the code file. In the attached image, I change the first line to var imageRange = context.document.getSelection() as Word.Range;. Word.Range showed as IntelliSense (auto-completion) 2) Then the type checker gives the warning you see in the image, 'Property X does not exist on type Y.' This behavior is correct as that property is not listed in the .d.ts file. (it is in the js library). 3) Then, if I remove the as Word.Range conversion from the first line, I'd expect that the warning would go away since I'd expect that the type check would go away. The actual behavior is that it looks like it is using a type check cache -- I removed the type conversion for the variable but it still states that the property doesn't exist on the object. I'd expect that message to go away as the code doesn't provide the object type. ![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8527305/12442639/6e3cf968-bf06-11e5-8f6a-02cc4213c9f2.PNG)
